40952954.review:
通常Adventure ModeをクリアしてNG+挑戦中。
所謂不思議ダンジョン的なローグライクRPG。

空腹とか武器防具耐久とか、面倒臭い設計が無い不思議ダンジョン。
でも回復手段が限られ制限もありChampionモンスターはとんでもなく厄介で、脳筋プレイを許さない難易度。
死んでもほぼ無問題のモードから全消去のモードまで、ユーザーで選べる親切設計。
ジョブは様々スキルは大量、自分だけのスタイルでやっていける。
飽きない敵の種類の多さ。好きな敵を捕まえて味方にできたりも。
やり込み要素も十分。
BGMは最高。キーコンフィグから何から何まで痒い所に手が届く配慮の塊の設定とプレイ環境。
ドットも素敵。
日本語化も来る。
更新もとんでもなく早い。
どこをとっても文句ない高水準なゲームだと思います。

ちょこちょこバランス崩壊スタイルや死んでるスタイルがありますがご愛嬌。
それに気づくまでも、気づいた後に自分で制限かけるのもローグライクの楽しみ。
この手のゲームでは当然ですがあんまり調べない方が良いと思います。

不思議ダンジョン的なのが好きなら即座に買いだと思いますので是非。

死ぬと全てを失うハードコアモード一周クリア時点の感想
*他のモードはやってません

「不思議のダンジョン」という言葉が他のレビューで使われていますが、アイテムの入手方法の比重がモンスタードロップや店での購入に偏っています。店も非戦闘エリアで行き来ができる拠点に最初から存在します。
故に、探索で床落ちのアイテムを拾い戦闘は主に経験値のために行うという「不思議のダンジョン」スタイルとはかけ離れたものとなっています。
他の作品を引用して例えるなら「Angband」、もしくはハクスラ系作品のハードコアモードというのがより近いです。

「不思議」よりもかなり戦闘の比重が高いというだけでしっかりとした(エセではない)ローグライクではありますので、ハクスラっぽいのも楽しめるよと言う方にはぜひおすすめです。

The game rocks, but oh boy is it hard af! This is a refreshing roguelike that has a death progression system that doesn't allow you to play the same character (on hero mode), but lets you inherit weapons and armor from any runs that you have survived in and stored in a special item box.

40691814.review:
I've beaten the game. 
Main Points: 
[list] 
[*] A real roguelike, with MMO spell style combat similar to ToME 
[*] A very long campaign for a roguelike
[*] The loot hunt, level up system, campaign, etc... feels similar to ARPG's. Except it's turn based instead of RT. 
[*] No grinding, just play the campaign, but leveling up anything is super expensive and time consuming
[*] Leveling up all the way is overkill to beat the game
[*] Finite hp per playthrough, but with health management you have more than enough

Overall, a very nice experience. You can expect to spend the first many hours dying at lower stages. Number 1 tip, play slowly and take your time. Endgame is a long grind to kill many strong enemies very carefully.

40499122.review:
Probably the best classic style roguelike. Better than Dungeonmans, Dredmor or The pit (3 very good games)

PROs :
-Very cool graphics and music. It's more beautiful than others classic rogulikes.
-LOt oF LoOt, 4 weapon slots, rarity and tier system for items
-Job system allowing varied builds 
-Difficult <3 (you can play on hardcore mode for real permadeath sensations)
-You can cook some food by crafting items, and choose well between consume food or potions
-You can upgrade your items by clearing some extra maps. Thoose maps have some specific interesting rules.
-No hunger clock !! You will feel so free to move !! ^^
-LInear progression (thanks, there is no worldmap), but you can choose your path between 2 options sometimes.
-Money is rare, and you have so much things to do with. Spend it with intellingence :)
-You can choose 2 perks in a list for your character at the beginning.
-Secrets areas and shops

CONs
-You can raise pets. It is an interesting gameplay feature, but it take lot of time, it breaks the rythme of the dungeon crawling, and pets are weaks.
-Some rumors (side quests) are boring, like you have to go few floors back to kill 3 monsters.... You only can have 3 rumors at a time, and if you cancel one, you have to wait one or two nexts floors to pick an other one, mayby more interesting.
-To many go and returns between the dungeon and the hub / village (if you want to have an optimised run and go far in the game. And you want ^^). In addition, the village is big and you have to walk too many for using the differents elements in there (shops, rumors, weapon master, pet corral, map machine, trees field, dungeon entrance, ...). It breaks the rythme of the adventure too many times.
-No wands with charges, no identify system, no weapon crafting, only one slot for armor (torso) equiment (no boots slots of gloves slot or belt slot, no ring and amulets slots, for all of this, you have only two slots named "accessories". But don't worry, the game is balanced around this feature.)
-There is no monster zoo rooms (like in dredmor)
-Secret walls are too obvious. Discover secret rooms is not in relation with a specific stat.

Conclusion : buy it !!!!!

40189749.review:
Tangledeep is an absurdly charming, nostalgic game that invokes warm memories whilst actually having something to contribute to the roguelike genre.

Aesthetically, it's an amazing piece of media - the spritework and environments are beautiful, the animations are cute, and the music is incredible (to be expected really, considering the developer). It references classics like Secret of Mana heavily, but manages to maintain its own character in spite of that.

Mechanically, it's generally very straightforward - you choose a starting Job, which gives you a skillset you can upgrade as you complete milestones and defeat monsters. If you want (and you'll definitely want to) you can even switch Jobs, keeping all the abilities you've unlocked for use with the new Job. A combo I've really enjoyed is matching Bandit with Budoka to build a tricksy, lightning-fast character who can deal bone-crushing sneak attacks. 

The monster design in Tangledeep makes every enemy unique and interesting - most monsters can always pose some kind of threat, whether it's poison, paralysation, or just being absurdly dangerous at one distance or another, and since your resources are extremely limited, you have to think carefully about how you approach each threat.

Possibly the most controversial design choice is non-recovering resources - most roguelikes let you regain HP, Stamina etc. over time, but in Tangledeep, the only way you get those resources back is by killing monsters or using items. Some players may find this stressful, but it forms an incentive to keep pushing forward, be smart with your skills and make good use of the cooking system, which is robust and forms a keystone of survival in Tangledeep.

There are some meta-progression elements in the game, as is common for many roguelikes these days, but nothing that I would say would ever make a win guaranteed in the end - there's persistent item / gold storage, pet rearing and an orchard for growing food and cash, but none of this can be a substitute for good play.

I'm excited to see this project continue to develop, and with any luck it'll eventually enter the roguelike cannon as one of the great examples of the genre!

40065626.review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gFyTjc9ZomM

Więcej informacji (+nieco porad) w pełnym opisie:
http://hakimodo.pl/2018/02/14/tangledeep-rpg-w-starym-stylu-lecz-w-nowym-wydaniu/


OCENA POZYTYWNA. Gra mnie nieco wciągnęła choć na początku trzeba się przyzwyczaić do jej obsługi i zrozumieć czym są Job Points i w jaki sposób z nich korzystać. Trochę zamotany jest także system przepisów z których przyrządzamy potrawy. Poziom trudności jest zbalansowany (choć nie jest nazbyt łatwo).


++ PLUSY +++
+ przyjemny dla oka wygląd (choć może nieco nazbyt rozpikselowany)
+ wciągająca rozgrywka (choć może nieco nużąca na początku)
+ autor realizuje pomysły graczy co cieszy. Sam pożaliłem mu się na wygląd mapy i została ona dosyć szybko poprawiona 🙂
+ bogate wnętrze gry – dużo do rozkminienia (wiele klas postaci, mechanika rozgrywki)
+ gra niespodziewanie po pokonaniu bossa z łatwej przechodzi na znacznie trudniejszą więc rozgrywka wymaga więcej kombinowania
+ proceduralnie generowany świat – rozgrywka na więcej niż jeden raz.


—-- MINUSY —--
- Zamotany system przepisów z których przyrządzamy potrawy (jeśli wybierzemy złe składowe, np. zamiast 2 owoców – owoc i warzywo – stracimy je). Przepisy można podejrzeć lecz przy sporządzaniu trzeba pamiętać składowe – czy nie można było po prostu wyświetlić możliwych do realizacji wyników?
- Nieco mało ergonomicznie zostało rozwiązane użycie umiejętności specjalnych – np uderzenie tarczą nie działa gdy mamy w ręku łuk i trzeba najpierw zmienić broń (nie powoduje to utraty ruchu) i dopiero wtedy zadziała. Po tym znów biorę do ręki łuk i kontynuuję ostrzał – można było uniknąć tej zmiany oręża skoro go i tak posiadamy.
- Nieco niezbalansowana różnica pomiędzy walką dystansową i w zwarciu (ta jest trudniejsza)
- Gracz nieco nazbyt szybko (pokonanie 1-go bossa) ląduje na głębokiej wodzie – gra robi się nieco trudniejsza choć nie zdołaliśmy jeszcze w pełni poznać mechaniki gry.



=== WPROWADZENIE ===
Gra jest dziełem studia Impact Gameworks. Została wydana jako gra Early Access a swoje początki miała na Kickstarterze gdzie prowadzona kampania pozwoliła uzyskać niemal dwukrotność zakładanego pierwotnie budżetu. W grze za zadanie mamy wydostać się z podziemnej wioski i sprawdzić co kryje się ponad nami, kierując się stale ku powierzchni. W tym celu musimy nauczyć się efektywnie walczyć, poznać słabe strony przeciwników a także wyuczyć różnych umiejętności, które odpowiednio użyte zwiększą naszą przewagę w trakcie starć.


=== GRAFIKA I MUZYKA ===
Grafika jest wzorowana w stylu retro 16-bit i prócz rozpikselowanej mapy wygląda całkiem przyzwoicie. Widok planszy oraz przeciwników jest przedstawiony w lekkim rzucie izometrycznym. W razie konieczności możemy w menu włączyć także stylowe skanowanie rastrowe (scanline) dzięki czemu wyświetlany obraz upodobni się do starych wyświetlaczy. Postaci są wykonane z dbałością o szczegóły, choć zwróciłem autorowi uwagę, że popełnił błąd logiczny – główna postać trzyma broń w lewej ręce, tarczę w prawej – gdy zaś ją widzimy od tyłu – w przeciwnych. Teren oraz przeciwnicy wygląda ją schludnie i nie ma problemów z interpretacją na czym stoimy czy też z czym walczymy. Postać jak i wrogowie są z lekka animowane (kilka klatek), podobnie jak i wykonywane akcje.
Oprawa dźwiękowa stoi na przyzwoitym poziomie – dodatkowo w grze przygrywa nienużąca muzyka (którą oczywiście można w razie konieczności wyciszyć).


=== ROZGRYWKA ===
=== Cel gry ===
Rozpoczynamy w podziemnej wiosce a naszym zadaniem jest sprawdzić co znajduje się ponad nami, kierując się ku powierzchni. W tym celu gra powoli zapoznaje nas z dostępnym asortymentem oraz uczy nas radzenia sobie z ekwipunkiem. Stopniowo, poziom po poziomie będziemy piąć się coraz wyżej.
 

=== Trudność rozgrywki ===
Gra ma trzy poziomy trudności, wybierane na starcie przy tworzeniu postaci:
- najłatwiejszy (Adventure Mode) – gdzie ginąc odrodzimy się w wiosce tracąc nieco przenoszonego złota, doświadczenia oraz JP (job points). Przedmiotów nie tracimy
- normalny (Heroic Mode) – ginąc tracimy cały ekwipunek
- permadeath (Hardcore Mode) – śmierć oznacza koniec rozgrywki. Przegrana usuwa także save.
 

=== Tutorial (samouczek) ===
Sam w sobie nie istnieje jako odrębne wprowadzenie. Z zasadami rozgrywki oraz nowymi rzeczami jesteśmy zaznajamiani w trakcie naszej podróży. Dlatego też początek zajmie ci nieco więcej czasu ponieważ trzeba nieco poczytać i zapoznać się z opisami dostępnych możliwości.


=== Sterowanie ===
Naszą postać możemy sterować używając jedynie myszki ale wygodniejszym rozwiązaniem jest drugi z systemów sterowania gdzie możemy używać zarówno myszy jak i klawiatury. W tym wypadku klawiatura numeryczna służy nam za wskazywanie postaci w którym kierunku może się przemieścić. Ja w trakcie rozgrywki prawie nie używałem myszki, znacznie wygodniej używało mi się klawiatury. I kilka zasad:
Układ klawiszy możesz przypisać w menu samodzielnie
Spacja powoduje pominięcie tury ruchu. Przydatne by poczekać aż przeciwnik wejdzie w nasze pole rażenia.
 

=== Początki gry ===
Na początku rozgrywki nie jest aż tak trudno ponieważ przeciwnicy nie są aż tak wymagający. Poziom trudności nieco wzrasta gdy zaczniemy się zagłębiać podążając ku dalszym poziomom. Warto się przygotować i mieć zawsze w zapasie nieco pożywienia by móc w razie potrzeby odzyskać nieco zdrowia. Dlatego też nie warto sprzedawać specyfików odzyskujących życie ponieważ przydadzą ci się w dalszej podróży.

Wraz z kolejnymi stoczonymi walkami pozyskasz nieco dropów tak więc będziesz mógł je spieniężyć i tym samym zarobić trochę grosza, Polecam zakup dobrego łuku (zasięg 4 pól) co pozwoli atakować przeciwników z oddali. Nim ci zbliżą się do nas stracą już nieco zdrowia.

Nieco denerwujące jest rozwiązanie tyczące się dodatkowego ekwipunku – dla przykładu mamy cztery sloty na broń zaś jeśli posiadamy w nich miecz oraz łuk to w ekwipunku możemy mieć tarczę (używana gdy dzierżymy miecz) lub kołczan ze strzałami (jeśli trzymamy łuk). Tym samym trzeba uważać byśmy nie sprzedali jednego z nich w sklepie ponieważ jeśli nie jest używany, przechowywany jest w plecaku i trzeba na to uważać by przypadkiem tego nie opchnąć handlarzowi przy pozbywaniu się zdobytych gratów (co mi się już zdarzyło). Odkupienie naszego przedmiotu rzecz jasna jest nieco droższe niż jego sprzedaż.

Jeśli mowa o samym wprowadzeniu gracza w arkana rozgrywki to zostało to rozwiązane dosyć dobrze. Co prawda to jak działa część rzeczy oraz w jaki sposób właściwie z nich korzystać zrozumiałem nieco później. Trzeba uważnie czytać kolejne przedstawiane porady – lub zapoznać się z poradnikiem, który zapewne stworzę po przejściu gry.


=== Rozwój postaci ===
Jak każda gra RPG tak i tutaj wraz z pozyskiwaniem punktów doświadczenia otrzymamy do dyspozycji możliwość wyboru pewnych umiejętności i ukształtowania swojego dalszego rozwoju. Przede wszystkim wszystko kształtuje wybór bohatera na starcie gry – każdym gra się nieco inaczej, każdy z nich posiada nieco inne drzewko umiejętności  i to wg tych wyborów będziemy ją prowadzić.
Wraz z pokonywaniem kolejnym wrogów będziemy pozyskiwać pieniądze, doświadczenie (XP) oraz „jednostki pracy” (Job Points).
Doświadczenie podbija nasz poziom. Skok o poziom to podbicie bazowych parametrów postaci (życie, stamina itp.) Nie mamy wpływu na rozdział tych punktów.
Job Points pozwalają na zakup (naukę) umiejętności specjalnych – wybieramy jedną z dostępnych. Wyższy poziom zaawansowania to niestety konieczność zapewnienia większej ich ilości. Dzielą się one na pasywne (działające stale / samodzielnie) bądź aktywne – gdzie musimy płacić energią czy też wytrzymałością (stamina) za ich użycie.

맵이 지나치게 단조롭고 말고를 떠나서 난이도 상승구간이 아직까지도 조절 제대로 안됨.

이 난이도 상승구간을 헤쳐 나가기 위해선 레벨과 장비를 맞추는게 당연하지만 이 게임은 만렙이 고작 15,

액트 3를 지나는 시점에서 이미 만렙을 찍는데 적들은 계속해서 강해짐. 

위에 장점에 써놓은 '적당히 있는 컨텐츠'들을 통해서 강해져야 하는데 이게 지나친 노가다를 요구하고 직관적이지 못해 난해함.

외국유저들도 이 구간을 지나는 시점에서 큰 피로감을 느껴서 이탈함.

텐트는 레어 소모품, 캠프파이어는 층 뚫을 때 어쩌다 나옴, 아이템 드림 던전도 입장권이 소모품이고 던전이라 난이도 낮은 곳으로 안가면 오히려 귀한 포션과 음식을 더 쓰고 나옴.

그리고 죽고나면 가지고 있는 자원들(경험치, 돈, 스킬용 경험치)를 전부 절반씩 잃어 버리는데, 이 엄청난 데스 페널티가 위의 한정적인 자원상황과 미친 조합을 일으켜 좆망의 스노우 볼링을 일으킴.

그리고 마을에서 받을 수 있는 치료나 창고 서비스(특히 유니크)가 지나치게 비싸서 이용할 엄두를 도저히 낼 수가 없음. 근데 시간 지난다고 자동으로 치료 되는 것도 없음. 결국 한정된 소모품 자원으로 어찌어찌 치료 하거나 걍 돈내고 치료하거나 둘 중 하나임

로그라이크 골수 유저들에겐 어필 하기 힘든 가벼움. 로그라이트를 바라는 사람들이 하기엔 너무 어려운 게임.
제작진들의 신기에 가까운 레벨 디자인 덕에 부분유료 결제 서비스가 막힌 핵과금 유도 게임 하는 기분 들음.

40014032.review:
Extremely fun Roguelike/RPG hybrid with a lot of depth and style.  The soundtrack is outstanding and many of the tracks would not sound out of place in any of the great SNES RPG classics.  The classes are all very unique and the ability to switch classes but keep passives and active skills from others that you have used on that character allows for a large amount of builds.  

The difficulty is well balanced, if you rush into things headlong, you are likely to die.  If you take your time, especially when engaging multiple enemies at once, you can survive what you otherwise wouldn't.  It also has three game modes, the standard Roguelike "Heroic" difficulty, where you die, you lose your character, but save certain things on the file and can start a new character.  Adventure mode, where you keep your character, lose half your currencies, and go back to town.  There is also Hardcore mode, where if you die, the save file is deleted and all progress on that file is lost. 

Don't forget movement skills!  They are life savers, and can help you avoid environmental hazards as well as enemies, also don't forget to use a ranged weapon, even if you are a "melee" class, it never hurts to hit a monster a few times while it closes in.  

Overall, this game is fantastic and I strongly reccomend it if you like RPGs like Chrono Trigger, Secret of Mana, Final Fantasy VI, or if you like Roguelikes like Dungeonmans.  

10/10 would die again.

39998846.review: Ok, this is an amazing game. I must admit is kind of generic when compared to classic & standard rogue-likes, but what misses in depth it earns in presentation and addictive gameplay. The game is rich in modes so it can be both hardcore and kind-of-casual friendly. I was following this game since the early stages of development and only bought it when it reached state 1.0 just to make sure I wasnt missing any parts of it. I believe I was correct. The game as of now is a coherent and engaging experience. Bit hard for the newcomers in terms of difficulty but at the same time very beginner friendly in terms of game mechanics. 39992581.review:
The brainchild of one-man studio Impact Gameworks, Tangledeep is at first sight a wonderful throwback to the 16-bit SNES RPGs of the 90s, particularly reminiscent of Secret of Mana. Set in a verdant and magical underground world full of weird creatures and talking animals, you must roam through Tangledeep: a route to the surface through procedural maze levels.

As a roguelike dungeon crawler it is quite challenging, especially on heroic and hardcore modes, where permadeath resets the character, or all progress (hardcore). There is also the adventure mode for more roguelite casual play, though some roguelike enthusiasts might say the inclusion of this mode makes the game more of a roguelite.

Influenced by roguelikes such as Tales of Maj’Eyal and Dungeonmans, Tangledeep may not be as full-on hardcore as those games, but then it doesn’t have to be, aimed as it is at a broader audience with the nostalgic SNES aesthetic. It’s an accessible roguelike rather than a roguelite, delivering a full experience beyond the challenge for challenge’s sake.

39961471.review:
[h1]いろんなゲームのいいとこ取りしたローグライクRPGの決定版！？[/h1]

※ただし、現状日本語はありません。開発スタッフが日本のゲームシーンをしっかり見据えており、日本語ローカライズについて「すぐにとは言えないが、おそらくやる」とのこと(昨年の発言)

ついにアーリーアクセス抜けて正式リリースにこぎつけた、ハイクオリティなローグライクRPGです。
プロシージャル生成やパーマデス、ターンベースバトルなどいわゆる「古典的」ローグライクのお約束をおさえて、操作性や一本道に近いゲームの進行・若干の蓄積要素など「不思議のダンジョン」シリーズに近いプレイ感を実現しつつ、空腹度・フロアでの時間制限といった(どんどん先に進まなければいけない)要素をスパッと切っています。加えて、クールダウンのあるスキル(スタミナ・エナジー二種のリソースを消費)を多数組み合わせて駆使する前提の戦闘バランスなどは、直接的には[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/259680/Tales_of_MajEyal/]Tales of Maj'Eyal[/url]から影響を受けているのかなと思います。

難易度は三段階から選択することができます。
一番簡単 - 倒れても経験値・金が減るだけでレベル1には戻らない。初心者もとっつきやすい。
中間 - 倒れるとレベル1から。ただし倉庫やペットなど引き継ぎ可能。「不思議のダンジョン」。
ハードコア - 倒れるとキャラ消失。倉庫も引き継ぎ不可。「変愚蛮怒」や「Nethack」育ちのあなたに。
(3難易度共通で、初期フィート、キャラクタークラスのアンロック要素あり。セーブスロット単位)

[h1]超ハイクオリティなドットグラフィックと音楽[/h1]

このゲームの大きな魅力は、内容のガチさに似合わぬその可愛いグラフィックと、めちゃくちゃハイクオリティな音楽。グリグリアニメーションする可愛いドット絵は「風来のシレン」などの日本製コンシューマーローグライクと比べても全く見劣りするところがなく、BGMに至ってはSFC全盛期のスクエアRPGを彷彿とさせる、(特に聖剣伝説2-3。というかTangledeepのサントラには菊田裕樹さんがゲスト参加してます)、おじさんゲーマーには特にたまらないものになっています。[url=https://zirconstudios.bandcamp.com/album/tangledeep-original-soundtrack]Bandcampでサントラの全曲試聴が可能です。[/url]サントラ買う時はSteamでDLC買う方が安く、FLACとmp3同梱で完璧です。(ゲーム本体買ってないとダメですが)

それに加え、キーボードオンリー/キーボード+マウス/コントローラー、どの操作方法でも快適にプレイ可能な、よくできたユーザーインターフェース。とかくグラフィック(アニメーション)やBGMが軽視されがちなPCローグライクというジャンルにあって、このトータル面での高級感は、まさに破格です。

ランダムドロップのアイテムにはマジック効果のある修飾子がつくことがあり、このへんはハック＆スラッシュっぽくてアイテムハントのロマンもあります。モンスターを捕まえてエサをあげたりトリミングしたりして育てる「ポケモン」（或いはドラクエV？）のような要素も。さらに、ゲームの序盤を抜ける頃にとある方法でアイテムの真の力を引き出す(アイテムごとに強敵を倒す必要あり)ことが可能になったり、武器の種類ごとに存在するWeapon Masteryスキル(奥義を除いて複数種の習得が可能)など、色々なゲームからおいしい部分をアレンジして実装しているという感じ。それらがちゃんとゲーム的にまとまって(調和して)いるのが素晴らしい。

[h1]総合評価[/h1]

総合的に見てハードコアローグライカーからライトゲーマーまで納得のクオリティ。いままで、ローグライクに馴染みの薄い人にも気兼ねなくオススメできる(Steamでの)鉄板といえば[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/212680/FTL_Faster_Than_Light/]FTL: Faster Than Light[/url]、[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/247080/Crypt_of_the_NecroDancer/]Crypt of the Necrodancer[/url]、[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/113200/The_Binding_of_Isaac/]The Binding of Isaac[/url]など、ローグライクの「定義」的にはちょっと変化球的なものが多かったのですが、ついに「古典的」ローグライクの直系でライトユーザーにも遊びやすく、安っぽさも感じないであろう鉄板作品が出たなという感じです。英語がダメでなければ、間違いなく面白いのでぜひ遊んでみて下さい。

39957678.review:
Ce jeu échoue là où la plupart des rogue-like modern réussissent: au niveau de la rejouabilité. Tout l'intérêt d'une "run" de Binding of Isaac ou de FTL par exemple, c'est de réussir à s'adapter aux outils que le jeu nous donne. L'approche de Tangledeep est complètement inversée et c'est le défaut majeur du jeu: le joueur choisit un "build" au début du jeu, doit s'y tenir, et il n'a plus qu'à prier/grind pour avoir les bons objets qui vont avec. Deux runs sur Tangledeep avec le même personnage seront quasiment similaires, là où 10 runs avec le même vaisseau sur FTL seront toutes complètement différentes par exemple.

Tangledeep échoue aussi au niveau de l'aspect stratégique: on fait attention à son placement pendant les premiers niveaux, mais les monstres gagnent très vite des capacités de déplacement qui rendent caduque tout travail de positionnement. Certains monstres invoquent même des tornades qui se déplacent de manière complètement aléatoire et attirent périodiquement le joueur au centre, sans aucun contre possible. Les combats deviennent rapidement des stats-check où on spam les sorts et les consommables en espérant survivre.

Et justement, si le jeu se veut difficile, c'est avant tout parce qu'il est extrêmement mal équilibré avec des pics de difficulté ridicules. Le jeu limite fortement la régénération de santé, et comme les classes corps-à-corps disposent de peu de moyens de gagner en résistance, elles sont complètement inutiles par rapport aux classes à distance qui peuvent hit & run. Les monstres élites commencent rapidement à taper dans les 20-25% de vie max par tour, et la plupart de leurs bonus se limitent à "fait très très mal" de différentes manières, sans moyen de jouer autour.

Le jeu se vante aussi de disposer de beaucoup de mécanismes de progression, mais la plupart sont complètement inutiles. Il est par exemple possible de capturer et d'élever des monstres pour aider au combat, mais ils ne peuvent pas gagner de niveaux et demandent beaucoup trop de temps et de ressource à être prêt au combat. Il y a énormément de nourritures différentes, mais comme on ne peut en prendre que tout les X tours, tout celles qui ne rendent pas de vie deviennent inutiles. Les marchands ont un choix d'objet limité et de bas niveau, et upgrader les objets est très cher et trop risqué.

C'est aussi un échec en terme de QoL, l'inventaire est digne de celui des premiers Pokémon, les déplacements sont saccadés, le personnage équipe automatiquement des équipements qu'on utilise involontairement et qui en déséquipe d'autres (notamment les arcs qui déséquippent les boucliers), et il arrive parfois qu'on attaque des monstres pacifiques en désignant une case complètement différente. J'ai aussi remarqué un nombre particulièrement important de missclick: si on joue trop rapidement à la souris, le système de visée déconne et peut pointer jusqu'à 3-4 cases à coté.

Tangledeep est un jeu bourré d'idées intéressantes, mais qui ne fonctionnent pas du tout une fois mises ensemble. Il est évident que les développeurs ont beaucoup travaillé sur le jeu quand on voit la variété des expériences qu'ils essayent de proposer, mais malheureusement le résultat est un mauvais rogue-like, et un mauvais RPG tour-par-tour.

39950009.review:
[i]Tangledeep[/i] is a strange title.  Reminiscent of [i]Rogue[/i], [i]Nethack[/i], and other early turn-based, dungeon-crawling RPGs, the game leavens the infamous difficulty of the genre by doing away with most of the complexities and vagaries of its predecessors, as well as by adopting the common “rogue-lite” element of persistent progress.
 
On the default difficulty of the game, you can pass on items and gold, among other things, to future characters after your current character meets her grisly fate at the claws of the strange creatures of Tangledeep.  There is an easier mode that allows you to continue playing the same character after you die, and a hardcore mode that deletes your progress entirely.  One of the highlights of the game is its dynamic job system, which allows you to switch between classes on a single character in order to mix and match acquired skills and abilities to create a customizable fighter.  I was reminded of [i]Final Fantasy V[/i], which for me was a good thing.  Unfortunately, that was probably the high point of my experience. 

The main problem with [i]Tangledeep[/i] is that there’s just not very much here. As is my policy, I selected the hardest difficulty upon starting the game—hardcore mode. I expected to die a few times, but I was well aware of the inherent danger of roguelikes (especially roguelite variants).  They tend to be content light, depending on the player to die repeatedly in order to artificially extend the game’s experience.  I didn’t want to trivialize the game too quickly.  Unfortunately, I just ended up beating the game on my first try. Sick brags; the end. 

. . . In all seriousness, though, [i]Tangledeep[/i] somehow fails to justify the existence of its own mechanics.  For example, there is a Monster Pen where you are able to keep captive monsters and breed them in order to make monster companions to accompany you on your adventures (something like [i]Dragon Quest Monsters[/i]).  After a few feeble attempts at feeding the two pathetic monsters I captured, I just gave up on it.  I had no real need for a monster companion, and the entire system was just anemic and . . . well, not fun.  I haven’t tried New Game + (and don’t intend to), but I don’t see things suddenly improving the second time around.

By the way, you may have noticed I keep referring to older games in this review.  That’s not a coincidence—there’s really not a single original idea in this entire game.  It just takes a bunch of things that have been done before and mashes them together.  Sometimes, that can be novel in and of itself, but in this case it’s just a hot mess. Nothing really works together and I’m not sure what the vision was. 

Much of the excitement of customizing your character is ruined when things don’t work due to hidden information or bugs.  At one point, I picked up a passive skill from the Claw mastery category for my fist-fighting character.  The skill purported to make me immune to paralysis and attack down effects, something I was sorely missing.  Within two minutes, I got paralyzed by the first monster I encountered.  Nowhere in the skill description did it tell me that this passive only worked with claws (which is what I assume to be the case; I didn’t test it), but similar passives are very specific in telling you that they only work with a certain weapon type.  It’s just inconsistent, as if no one really bothered to test anything about the game. 

The interface is a bit wonky—nothing terrible, but not as polished as it should be.  Perhaps the worst part is that you only get two hotbars to switch between for your skills, despite the fact that you could easily acquire tons of skills.  If you want to use anything more than what you have available on your hotbar, you have to stop the action to choose your skills manually from a menu.  Why?

The items are 99 percent worthless, and yet they keep dropping without end, just cluttering up your screen.  The absolute worst is the food—if you are taking the game at all seriously and playing safely, you will quickly realize that you can very rarely use any kind of food that doesn’t heal you, because there is a shared cooldown.  You simply can’t afford the risk of getting caught out without being able to use food to heal yourself. 

Perhaps among the worst disappointments of the game are the bosses.  Roguelike bosses always tend to be a bit generic, as designers shy away from ending the player’s run due to an unexpected quirk, but these are as vanilla as they come.  I literally walked up to the final boss and punched it until it died.  Probably the easiest part of the game.

Thanks for sticking with me through this rambling tale.  Ultimately, there is no real depth or difficulty to [i]Tangledeep[/i].  If you play patiently and can endure the tedium, you will eventually win the game.  Unfortunately, you’ll feel like you lost—your investment of time, money, and tolerance washed down the drain.

39923045.review:
Tangledeep is one of those games I found while looking for roguelikes/roguelites at 1:00 AM in the morning. It looked like a pretty typical, dime-a-dozen roguelike at first glance, but after playing it for an hour or two, I was overwhelmed by the sheer joy the game has to offer. 

Tangledeep has a wonderfully nostalgic feel about it, but that doesn't mean it doesn't have its own personality. The music and art style will immediately throw you back into the classic SNES era, with character art reminiscent of Secret of Mana and music with that same familiarity, though like I said before, it also manages to maintain its own identity and create a nice, fairly relaxing (apart from the, y'know, you die, you're dead) atmosphere.

The gameplay is straight forward and I don't think I need explain much about it. It's a tile based system with actual animations so everything feels a bit more alive. You can use a controller or mouse and keyboard, though I haven't played it with a controller. Mouse and keyboard controls perfectly. 

The game has a total of twelve jobs (or classes) with the ability to switch jobs on the fly via consumable or by talking to an NPC at the Riverstone Camp, which serves as the world's hub. Each job offers unique skills and passive abilities you can equip at any time as long as you've unlocked them by spending JP (Job points). You'll have to actually play each job to unlock those skills though, as JP is unique to each. You'll get access to four passive slots and sixteen skill slots through two hotbars you can switch to at any time so there's plenty of character customization. Oh, and each weapon type also has skills that you can unlock for another layer of character building fun!

Tangledeep offers three difficulty settings, the easiest letting you just teleport back to camp when you die, the medium difficulty letting you keep any items you stored in camp and pets you've raised (I haven't explored the feature much, but it's there), and the hardest being TRU RAGU LYK.

It does have some flaws, however. At times, I found myself having to grind up a bit using the Dreamcaster, which creates a randomized dungeon from a piece of equipment. This allows you to upgrade your gear (but you won't be able to use this gear while in the item's "dream"). Unfortunately, if you find yourself overwhelmed in the dream and you manage to make it out, there's no way of ending that dream prematurely (except for an item you find IN the dream, which you'll lose if you teleport out). If you are having troubles in the main dungeon AND the dream dungeon, this could lead to some frustration. As I said before though, sometimes floors jump in difficulty, usually after a boss fight where you are generally starting to feel pretty confident. It's not a huge deal, and it's just a part of the game, but it is pretty unexpected to 
go from facetanking a boss and killing it in three or four turns to not being unable to move because Venosaur and his fifteen babies, his best friend Charizard the flamethrowing champion lizard, and a floating jewelery box all decided that it was just your time to go. But that might have just been bad luck.

There's also little things that could be improved upon, like when selling multiple items to a merchant, the sell window will close and you'll have to select the quantity that you want to sell. This is annoying if you have a lot of items. 

Unfortunately, Tangledeep also suffers from a few balance issues with ranged characters being arguably stronger than melee characters, but as far as I know, the developers are already working on those. 

Overall, I have really enjoyed my time with Tangledeep. It has a lot of content to enjoy for $14.99 and I would most certainly recommend it to anyone who enjoys roguelikes or roguelites, or even anyone who just likes RPGs in general. I don't usually write reviews, but I really felt like this game deserved a good one.

39921602.review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
Tangledeep is a great addition to the roguelike genre that gives the player the feeling that every decision has major consequences. A unique set of classes combine to make this a must have game for dungeon crawler enthusiasts.

[h1]Game Breakdown[/h1]
[u]Gameplay:[/u]
Tangledeep shares many of its gameplay systems with other roguelikes. The player picks up new equipment in a dungeon, one’s character becomes more powerful with a level up system, and the player’s goal is to reach the end of some great dungeon system. Tangledeep changes how many of these core systems work. 
The equipment system has been reworked so that your character has a main hand weapon, an offhand weapon, an armor slot, and two accessories. What makes this system interesting is that the armor and accessories are often found with a passive ability. These abilities feel powerful and I had difficulty deciding which one to choose. Tangledeep wants the player to adapt to the situation and change equipment as much as necessary. For this reason the player character is given a limitless inventory and four weapon slots which gives the player the chance to change weapons without requiring a turn. This creates a strategic layer to equipment that I have never seen before and is a great addition to the genre; no more set and forget equipment here!

As for the classes, they are enjoyable and unique. You choose one of nine initially unlocked classes with three yet to be unlocked. Every class feels unique and the level up system has a surprising twist. When you level up you only gain extra points in the five main stats. To gain skills you must first kill monsters to gain job points. Job points can then be used as a currency to buy your classes abilities from the “Learn Abilities” menu. The unique aspect of this system is that bought skills can be used if when you change classes. Changing classes is in fact encouraged as changing classes is incredibly cheap and the job change scroll is decently easy to find.

Finally, moving between floors is changed too. Other than moving upwards instead of downwards, players are given the chance to go up a second flight of stairs which can contain anything from a difficult maze with tons of loot, to an apple orchard with bunches of bananas strewn about. These are completely optional but end up being rewarding to complete.
Overall, Tangledeep on the surface uses every system from its predecessors and twists them all around to create something incredibly fun that we haven’t seen before.

[u]Story:[/u]
Tangledeep has a decent story that most importantly doesn’t get in the way of dungeon diving. The player is introduced to the world in a short cutscene after you start the game. You are then able to freely explore the starting area where you will meet the many characters who will work as quest givers and shop keepers. You get new bits of lore as you meet and defeat bosses, but otherwise you are left to defeat every monster you come across.

[u]Sound:[/u]
The sound design in this game is as good as other roguelikes but it doesn’t excel in this area. Impacts of weapon hits are decent and spells have good audio but nothing that ever wowed me. 

 [u]Music:[/u]
The music is exceptional in this title. It perfectly matches the mysterious forest feel that the game’s great graphics help to create. The sounds used to create the music are also of the SNES era, which is the era the developer attempted to capture in this game. I would say they had a great success. The music is on par with the classics of the genre such as Chrono Trigger and Secret of Mana. It adds so much ambience and energy to your adventure that it felt like a great piece of a great game instead of a burden. 

 [u]Graphics:[/u]
The SNES era pixel art graphics are amazing. The breathtaking forest and waterfalls, the well animated characters with fluid cape movement, and lively monsters all make Tangledeep’s world feel full of life and vitality. This can be hard to create in the pixel art, but the developer pulled it off spectacularly. 	

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[u]Pros:[/u]
Amazing Pixel Art
Great Twist on the roguelike genre
Every turn feels like it matters
Cooking is pretty fun

[u]Cons:[/u]
Inventory management can be a pain
Huge difficulty spikes

[u]Rating[/u]
[b]8/10[/b].

If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Original_Curators_Group#curation]Follow Original Curator Group[/url]

39904791.review:
A good roguelike that imitates the features of many of the rpg classics. The job system is similar to Final Fantasy Tactics, but trimmed down to fit the genre. Lots of thoughtful design choices, and the art is quite good... for the genre it comes from. Game mode determines how risky death is, and like the game, I recommend heroic. A death in heroic mode is expensive, but allows you to keep anything you didn't take into the dungeon.

Hardcore mode is only for those willing to plan every step in advance and who won't cry at losing hours of progress. Adventure mode is for those who want to experience the story with no obstacles in the way. I was impressed at how much better this game is than steam shovelware. I consider many games on steam to be tech demos and sandboxes, so it's always pleasant finding games like this one that have more than 10 hours worth of content to enjoy. Like Factorio, I'm 4 hours in and can already tell I'll be playing 50 hours minimum.

I love rogue-likes but it's very hard to get the time and focus together to really get into one. Though I have been making some progress in Caves of Qud, after a day at work it can be a little overwhelming.

Tangledeep, I find, is just about forgiving and friendly enough to play the evenings while still having lots of that decision making and RNG defying that makes a rogue-likes so fun. I definitely don't see it replacing more complicated games of this type but it fills a very interesting niche in the genre.

The SNES style graphics and music along with the anime influences are a bit of a put off for me but I find the game mechanics are strong enough to overcome that. I think there is a beautiful game here no matter how you feel about the aesthetic. 

Totally recommended as an entry level rogue like and a game I am very happy to see released on Steam.

39883078.review:
All I can say for this game is: [b]WOW[/b]. For hardcore roguelike enthusists, this may not be the game for you, it does not bring new and groundbreaking mechanics to the table and does not have sometimes unfair and hard luck based punishments. But this game does everything it did do right, making a simple game a very pleasurable experience. I'm giving this game a quick positive review because this game deserves love. 

Here's some pros and cons for those looking for lists:

[u]Pros:[/u]
[list]
[*] The game offers the sweet spot of difficulty custom fit to your level of challenge. The game will be easy to get you comfortable, but the game will challenge you greatly and you will feel fufilled after completing the challenges (after a few deaths).
[*] This game employs the Keep-It-Simple-Stupid system very well. The game mechanics and ability descriptions are easy to understand, letting the player play the game with full confidence in what they are doing.
[*] The graphics and music are pleasing upon first exposure, and a work of art upon further inspection.
[*] Fun, cute, and lighthearted sense of humor that plays off of other roguelikes and "geek references" (I'm sorry for making you cringe). This game will make you smile when you least expect it.
[/list]

[u]Cons:[/u]
[list]
[*] The game seems a bit short, the pricetag may be too steep for some buyers. If that is the case, wait for a steam sale, because this game is worth it.
[*] The game has some minor UI polishing to do that makes the game sometimes feel slightly awkward.
[*] The story for the game is minimal to moderate, the game is more focused on the roguelike experience than story. The characters, however, are quirky and have character.

Although I post this review as a positive there are several frustrating and annoying aspects of the game which almost push it to a negative,

Pro's - 

1. Graphics - To get this out of the way, I personally like the art style to this so theres not much else to say 

2. Bestiary - I love it when a game comes with a bestiary, expecially ones that add more in depth descriptions as you kill the enemy more, expecially useful when your asked to kill an enemy and cant remember what that enemy was

3. Item deams - This is an expecially nice part of the game, the basics are you get sent into a level and you climb a few floors eventually beating the boss, then you get an upgraded item with potantially new stats / abilities, as well as being stronger.

Gameplay - This one is a pro and con situation, the combat and general style of gameplay I personally like but as explained in the con section there are some parts of it which are a pain in the rear, the gameplay is grid based, you move then the enemy moves, some skills bypassing the turns so if your not into turn based games then might want to step aside

5. Class Variety - There's a total of 12 classes in game, 3 being unlockable throughout the game, as well as skills gained for each weapon in the game each having their own ultimate each class has its own abilities but there's not that much in terms of animation for these which is a shame

Overall the game can get frustrating, most of it was likely due to me playing as permadeath so it made the negatives stand out more, though it does say permadeath is as the game intended so I based the judgement on this yet all in all it is a good game that is fairly difficult if you prepare well enough most situations aren't that hard

39870052.review:
[h1]Tangledeep — простенький рогалик с атмосферой и визуалом как в классических JRPG[/h1]

Полный обзор: http://blast-games.ru/obzori/tangledeep-obzor-2018/

Моя история отношений с игрой Tangledeep – это тот случай, когда ты умом понимаешь, что игра, в общем-то, неплохая, но сердцу, как известно, не прикажешь. Я положительно не смог оценить в игре ничего, кроме графики и музыки, которые просто дернули в моей душеньке струнки, отвечающие за ностальгию по классическим JRPG играм. 

Геймплей очень медленный и скучный, лут неинтересный, локации однообразные, как и монстры. Битвы с боссами с челленджем, но так же скучны, как и все прочее. В игре есть еще возможность сажать что-то в саду, заводить питомцев и всякое такое, но я совершенно сознательно не стал писать об этом, потому что на мой игровой опыт ничего из этого не повлияло – мне стало скучно намного раньше, чем все это вообще пригодилось. 

Помимо того, что Tangledeep – это сплошной боредом, она еще и вызывает очень смешанные чувства из-за сочетания сеттинга и жанра. Не знаю, как у вас, но у меня жанр Roguelike ассоциируется с чем угодно, но не с JRPG alike сказочкой про девчушку, ищущую что-то там, зачем-то там. Все слишком доброе, слишком лучезарное и яркое. Временами я просто забывал, что играю в Roguelike и одна из причин – это сеттинг. Вторая – это очень низкая реиграбильность и мучительный путь до первого реального челленджа. 

[h1]Я было попытался припомнить похожие игры и вспомнил только одну – A Family of Grave Diggers, которая была примерно такой же мешаниной из концепта, понатасканных из других игр механик и скуки. [/h1]

39859393.review:
NOTE: I played 5 hours of this game on a different account!

Let me begin by saying I hate roguelikes and I hate retro-style games.
I will then immediately follow by saying I freaking love this game.

Roguelikes are too much for me because they're insanely complicated. Tangledeep's control flow and move rotation isn't trivial once you start getting stronger, but it's approachable enough that you can play it on a regular controller and still feel like you're a pro.

Additionally, Adventure mode lets you have a very difficult game without the insane punishment of having to start over and weigh insane risk in every encounter. You can get your teeth kicked in by a procedural death trap you just needed 2 extra turns to outsmart, take a deep breath, and head back in to try again. It's great!

The art is so insanely well done, and the OST is probably one of if not the best game OST of this genre.

That gets into what bothers me, typically, about retro games. Usually, indie game developers make retro games with the purpose in mind to capture a nostalgic feeling from an older time. They'll study the art, the music, the game design philosophies, and they'll replicate. That's kind of why I hate them; they definitionally add nothing new, and without the original expression of art those old games were trying to convey, the experience ends up this sort of empty shell.

To me, Tangledeep ranks right up with games like Shovel Knight for "games that do retro correctly". The idea is to use the magical feeling of an older aesthetic as a baseline to build new ideas on top of, not just to take a piece of history and copy it. And Tangledeep does that really well, for a few different reasons:

-Art. Tangledeep has beautiful 16-bit style pixel art. And yet, there's an element of modern touch to it, an extreme refinement that comes from people who are improving on the past, not mirroring it. The sprite sheets are thorough, the animations are crisp, clear, and elaborate. The environments are incredibly detailed. Seriously, stop and look at the waterfall in Riverstone Camp some time, and think about the last time you saw something like that in a retro game.

-Music. Tangledeep's soundtrack is an amalgamation of influences from Final Fantasy, Secret of Mana, and all kinds of other stuff. But the music is as much written by Zircon (Andrew Aversa) as it is written by those influences. His own melodic and harmonic voice that you hear in his EDM discography comes through the Tangledeep soundtrack. The music is comprised of very interesting and memorable compositions written by someone who grew up on amazing video game soundtracks, and does not at all sound like some chump in Fruity Loops trying to copy Nobuo or Kikuta (and no reason to, since Kikuta himself did a track here!). It really is amazing, and as deep as the game feels, the soundtrack quality is right there with it.

-Dialog. The dialog is bonkers. It's so witty and funny, and every NPC has some charming personality to them. Once the story kicks in later in the game, those personalities are really fleshed out every step of the way. It's not self indulgently high fantasy at all, and I really appreciate that. Nothing is worse than dry lore.

-Game mechanics. As I mentioned earlier, Tangledeep's control flow is great. So great, that even as a Roguelike, you can play it smooth as butter on a regular controller. Once you get the button shortcuts to access your skills into your fingers (which for me, happened by the end of the first level), you can really get into a rhythm fighting your way through the dungeons without fumbling around. It's very difficult, but so far I've been able to use my head to get out of most situations. The game is surprisingly balanced and well thought out in its skill trees and enemy stat scaling. The change jobs thing is freaking amazing, and mixing different class playstyles together really goes beyond what old SNES RPG's ever accomplished (even beyond what modern MMO's are trying to do successfully).

This game has some bugs, and it's Zircon's first video game, so that's sort of expected. I'm not gonna say it's perfect; there's been some unfair situations here and there, especially coming from bugs, but I promise that if you look past them (and they're patching them out diligently), this game is definitely a show stopper.

EDIT#2: After a eloquant response from the developer I decided to try this game again without  putting another games expectations on it. I'll leave the negative review for now but I am approaching it with more of an open mind.

I guess I'm always chasing the feeling I had while playing Castle Of the Winds. I was hoping that this game would be just htat but I was dissapointed. That may not be the games fault so I'll go ahead and list the good, what I hoped for but didn't see yet, and the bad that I experienced while playing. 

Good:
-Turnbased. 
-Procedurally generated "dungeons." 
-Music was good and relaxing.

What I hoped for but didn't get:
-In depth NPCs. 
-A underlining story arc.
-In Castle of the Winds you would sometimes open a room and all would be revealed in that room at once: glorious treasure with several hard enemies. You never knew what might be behind a door in COTW but you hoped it revealed something like that. This version of "Dungeons" was way to open and you would pedictably reveal an exact amount every step you took nothing look so planned out as those rooms in COTW.
-In COTW you started out by just punching things and you slowly built up your weapons and armor. However, in Tangledeep just one dungeon floor in I had already obtained 3 more weapons, 2 leather armors, and 2 sheilds.
-In COTW you had to indentify treasure or you could just risk it and put it on. It could be cursed or enchanted. Finding out the level of armor was so satisfying. As far as I can tell in tangledeep it's just simple stats on Armor. If there was more to it then it wasn't immedietly apparent.

The Bad:

-The Shop Inventory was not intuitive either.

39851394.developer_response:
When you redeem a key for a game on Steam, Steam marks it as "received for free" even if you got that game as part of a Kickstarter backer package or some other third party service.

So I'm not the primary developer on the team, that's Zircon. But I read all of your review and it actually made me smile. Tell you the truth? I loooove CoTW. I really do. It was one of the big inspirations behind another game I worked on called Dungeonmans. TD and CoTW are certainly different games. CoTW is a little more gritty and hard-scrapple, TD is brighter and a little more forgiving -- in the beginning at least.

In Castle of the Winds, you limp out of the first dungeon with a rusty sword, a hat that's probably cursed, and then you find someone burned your farm down.

In Tangledeep, you port back to town and a cheerful cat lady sings you a rhyme while buying your goods at a fair market price.

They're two different games. It makes me sad that you didn't enjoy TD but I can understand if your itch for CoTW wasn't scratched here. It *does* certainly tick up in difficulty after you pass the first story boss, but it never has that kick-down-the-door-and-yell-at-the-orcs feeling of CoTW. If anything, I feel like it works almost in reverse of that. The monsters roll up, you size up their powers and relative danger level, and you work to take care of them before more show up, or while moving to your next destination and trying to keep things under control. I have a good time with it, and the open spaces make all the mobility and AOE powers more useful.

It's also too bad that Tangledeep hurt you to the point where you wanted to warn other players away from it. That's unfortunate. But your feedback is still valuable and I appreciate it. Well and some of it made me chuckle -- for months the minimap had been too small and too hard to read. We updated it right before launch and so many players applauded, and now here's a negative review saying it's too big :D can't please 'em all.

Thanks for giving us a shot!

39825826.review:
This is a very well-made roguelike ( yes, an actual roguelike ) 

It features all the trappings you expect : turn based combat, tile based movement ( you move , enemies move same time) 
All actions use moves, there's multiple classes with varied special skills  - no two play the same - 

the way this differs from usual roguelikes is the progression - you can go up and down floors at will, even back to camp to buy / sell, make food, treat caught monsters, grow seeds and store gold.

This makes you able to level up a character, and go back for a rest ( you can save and quit at any time, as well ) 

the game gives you 4 save slots to run in - and depending what difficulty you set the game on - changes the way you play drastically.

Easy mode removes the permadeath - if you die , you return to camp with all your loot, gold, etc.

normal mode makes you lose all your loot, jp and xp.

hard mode makes you lose everything, every item youve ever collected, all gold, all xp, everything!

I enjoy the looks, it's got that perfect 16 bit charm.

The roguelike genre fits this game like a well tailored glove.

absolutley recommend this to anyone that enjoys roguelikes.

39814430.review:
I've just gotta say, wow.

This game scratches an intense RPG itch I've been having for a long time.  It kind of reminds me of Pixel Dungeon in terms of the combat, you being a lone adventurer and the monsters moving just after you move, but expands on it SO much more.  There is seriously so much depth to this game and so much progression for your character.

There are several classes each with their own unique active and passive skills you can purchase with skill points you acquire, and then there are several WEAPON types that also have their own set of skills you can buy with skill points if you wish to master your favorite weapons.  Your character levels up, you choose what stats to put points into, and battles a large variety of monsters (and sometimes fight special monsters with their own abilities a bit like Diablo III).

The game is a roguelike, but in the "default" difficulty of the game, you lose some experience/money/etc while keeping town upgrades and anything in the storage.  True roguelike and permadeath are also options for the brave.

This game is great, and if you like RPGs you'll probably like this.  I think I can sink a lot of hours into it.

 - 게임이 너무 쉽게 지루해질 수 있으니 '직업 변경' 시스템을 사용해 현재 직업의 스킬을 유지한 채 직업을 변경해보세요! 
    물론 강제로 시키진 않습니다만 클리어에 지장이 생길수도 있습니다.
 - '아이템 은행'을 사용해 당신의 다음 캐릭터는 게임을 좀 쉽게 진행하면 어떨까요? 
 - 와! 정기적으로 곡물과 향신료와 보석이 나오는 나무 키우기!



- 단점

1. 실패한 난이도 곡선

일단 게임 시작 시 플레이어는 ToME4 처럼 어드벤쳐 / 로그라이크 모드 선택이 가능함 이건 참 괜찮다고 생각함. 
일정 패널티를 안고 부활이 가능한 어드벤처로 시작 하실건가요?
아니면 캐릭터 데이터만 증발하고 아이템 볼트, 은행 등 요런 마을 데이터는 남아있게 할건가요?
그것도 아니라면 여타 로그라이크 게임과 같게 캐릭터 사망 시 모든 데이터가 날아가게 할건가요?

이렇게 총 3개의 모드가 존재하고 처음 시작하니 어드벤쳐나 골라서 해볼까요? 하고 가벼운 마음으로 시작함.

대충 하체가 선택하는 직업을 골라서 진행해도 첫 보스까진 스무스하게 처치 가능함. 문제는 그 이후에 난이도가 너무 지나치게, 빠르게 상승함. 

이 급격한 난이도 상승에 제일 큰 기여를 하는게 난이도처럼 심하게 빠른 몬스터 리젠인데. 첫번째 보스 처치 이후로는 다음 보스까지 가는 루트가 2개로 나뉘고, 다시 1곳으로 모이고 2개로 나뉘고 하는 식인데. 문제는 그 지형 중 개활지가 많이 포함되어 있는 지형이 있고, 아니 사실 개활지 그 자체지만. 처음 시작하는 플레이어가 그놈의 개활지로 진입하면 사방에서 잡아도 잡아도 계속해서 리필되는 몬스터에게 둘러쌓여 지옥을 맛볼 수 있는데...

이 게임을 하면서 그래도 던전 오브 드레드모어에 나오는 '몬스터 주' 인카운터 처럼 진짜 쌍욕 나오는 인카운터는 없겠지? 했는데
 끌 수도 없이 상시 켜져있는 몬스터 리젠이 딱 그꼴이였음.

거기에 여러 CC를 사용하는 입가에 웃음짓게 해주는 다양한 몬스터들.
안그래도 나오는 빈도가 높은데 흰템만 신나게 뿌리고 랜덤 스킬을 사용하는 엘리트 몬스터들.
게임 시작 시 2가지의 특성을 선택할 수 있는데 특성 중 엘리트 몬스터 출현 빈도 증가가 있는 걸 보고 '안 그래도 자주 나오는데 이걸 고르는 놈이 있나?' 큰 의문이 들었음.

바람에 이리 치이고 저리 치이다 땡겨지고 넉백 당하다 보면 '즈기요 선생님 양심이?' 싶을때가 많음.

타 리뷰를 보니 원거리 캐가 쉬우니 첫 캐로 근접은 별루에요 하는데 다음엔 정말 원거리 캐로 시작해봐야겠음... 수수께끼도 업는 팔라딘이라 문제엿겟지...


추가로, 이건 그냥 지극히 주관적인 의견이지만. 왜 벽파기를 1회성 아이템으로만 사용 가능하게 했을까 하는 아쉬움이 듬.

게임 자체가 몇몇 타 게임과 다르게 자동 탐색이나 계단 빠르게 찾기 기능이 존재하지 않는데 여러번 마주치다보면 속에서 암세포가 생기는 지형들이 랜덤 생성이다보니 생각보다 빈번하게 등장하고, 이런 지형으로 1:1 전투만 자주 유도할 수 있어도 난이도 하락 및 편의성에 괜찮은 기여를 할 수 있지 않았을까? 하는 생각이 들었음.

또 또 추가로... 아이템의 종류는 생각보다 다양함.

반지, 목걸이, 투구, 신발, 허리띠, 마스크 기타 등등.. 문제는 이 모든 다양한 아이템들을 무조건 2칸이라는 한정된 악세서리 칸에만 장착 가능하단 거고, 이건 좀 늘려주는게 좋지 않을까 싶은데. 


2. 아이템 강화 시스템

새벽까지 겜 달려서 벌써 기억이 가물가물한데 ToME4의 Far Portal 비스무리한 시스템이 존재함. 어디까지나 인던이.

메인 던전과 다른 인스턴트 던전으로, 첫 보스 처치 이후 여러 몬스터, 판도라 박스에서 레버리, 루시드, 스킬 오브를 드랍하고, 그 오브를 사용해서 아이템에 랜덤, 정해진 옵션을 부여함과 동시에 아이템 자체 스펙 증가.
물론 매직 옵션 추출도 가능하고, 골드를 추가로 사용하면 아이템 자체 스펙과 더불어 특정 옵션이 붙을수도 있고 이런 방식.

문제는 이게 좀 크게 지루하게 느껴질 수도 있고 심각하게 빡치는 상황이 많이 연출된단건데.자신이 JRPG 특유의 야리코미에 익숙한 사람이라면 이 방식을 크게 지루하게 느끼지 않을 수 있을거임.

위에서 대략적인 선택 방법은 설명했고 진행 방식이 드림 캐스터의 힘을 빌려 '해당 아이템의 꿈' 으로 진입해서 나오는 몬스터를 처치하고 아이템의 레벨에 따라 조정되는 층수까지 올라가 해당 아이템을 드랍하는 보스 몬스터를 처치해서 귀환하는 방식인데. 여기서도 마찬가지로 엘리트 몹들이 득실득실하고, 마지막 몬스터 걸리는게 완벽한 운빨이라 이동속도가 지나치게 빠른 시커 같은 몬스터가 걸리면 '야이 씹' 소리가 안 나올수가 없음. 자신이 근접 특화 캐릭터로 키웠다면.

흔히 보이는 엘리트 몬스터들은 '개구리 3마리' 소환 스킬을 사용하는데 옆동네 돌겜마냥 추방의 오라가 있는것도 아니고 정말 사리 쌓이는 상황이 많이 나옴. 사용 스펠 셋이 '대시' '개구리 소환' '자체 힐'인데 이게 진짜 정말로 진짜 뒤는 생략함.


3. 회복 매커니즘
개인적으로 이것도 난이도 상승에 한 몫 한다고 생각하는데, 이 게임의 HP, MP (에너지), 스태미너는 캐릭터가 대기를 한다고 해서
 자동으로 회복되지 않음. 물론 옆동네 겜마냥 100턴 휴식할 텀을 많이 주지도 않고.

회복할 수 있는 수단으로는.

- 맵 곳곳에서 나오는 분수에서 힐링 플라스크 획득 ( HP )
- 몬스터 '처치' 후 나오는 오브 획득
- 음식 섭취 or 조리 후 섭취, ( HP, MP, 스태미나 )
- 일정 구간마다 나오는 모닥불 (1회용)
- 마을로 이동 후 NPC '유료 힐'

이놈의 유료 힐 나와서 그냥 하는 얘긴데.... 캠프에 옹기종기 모여있고 포탈 보면 딱 디아블로 2 생각나서 '힐링은 당연히 무료로 해주시겠죠 힐러 선생님?' 하는 생각이 절로 나는데 이놈의 힐러는 플레이어가 뒤져가도 절대로 무료로 힐을 해주지 않음. '힐 비용이 너무 비싼거 아닌가요?' 하는 선택지가 존재하는데 누를 시 나오는 대사가 자연,,치유를,,빠르게,,허는게,,,절대루,,싼게아녀 ㅎㅎ,,, 글구.,, 싸게해주는거야... 힐가놈 거북이던데 그냥 한번 쑤셔서 용봉탕으로 만들어 버리고 싶다는 욕구가 샘솟는데 아쉽게도 PK가 불가능함.


아무튼 새벽이라 뭔가 주저리 주저리 엿같다 짜증난다 죽을 것 같다 죽이고 싶다 써놨는데 생각보단 괜찮은 게임이니 추천으로 마무리함.

여주만 이뻐도 반은 먹고 들어가기도 하고 재밌긴 하니까.

하지만 자신이 오래, 많이, 다회차를 할 수 있는 그런 게임을 원하는 플레이어라면 추천하지 않음.

39725466.review:
[b]tl;dr:[/b] A beautiful and surprisingly difficult roguelike with some flaws that will hopefully be improved upon.

From the very first moment, when you see the main screen of the game and hear the music, you will be immediately transported back 20+ years to when you first played Secret Of Mana.
The art is very well done, and the music is even better.
Not many games that go for a retro style actually manage to convey that feeling of a high quality product. This one does.

Now with those graphics, you might suspect that there must be a shortage of complexity, variance, replayability, difficulty.
I sure did. And was surprised.
Tangledeep is a surprisingly difficult roguelike with loads of stuff to do and enough reasons to replay it. If you ever make it to the end, that is. I didn't. Yet.

Once you beat the first boss, the difficulty ramps up significantly* and you are required to think about your every step as soon as you see an enemy. Use the right items, eat the right food, summon a creature, use your abilities... or run away. Everything is valid and you'll need to do all of it from time to time.

Replayability-wise, there are many classes (called jobs) to choose from, all of them different in abilities. And some clearly more challenging than others (in general, ranged classes are considered easier and I can agree).

But the game doesn't end there.
You also have the ability to catch pets, plant trees (it is more useful than it sounds), do quests, find secrets, enter the dreams of your items (not kidding)...
I will not say it is the most complex roguelike out there. It is not. But it is complex enough to keep you entertained for a long while.

[b]There are a few downsides, though:[/b]

* The difficulty spike after the first boss is just too much. Before you learn how everything works and just how careful you have to be, you will lose a number of characters right after the first boss. This is just weird and needlessly frustrating and should be changed to follow a more natural feeling difficulty curve.

Melee characters are much harder to play than ranged ones. It is just much easier to get surrounded and keeping your distance just isn't an option before later on when you can learn some techniques for ranged weapons, too.
The devs have already acknowledged that and it should be improved on release. But I have a feeling even then, ranged will be easier.

The UI can be clunky at times. For example, when you sell a single item in the shop, all is well. But when you click on a stack of items, the shop UI closes and a popup opens asking you how many of the stack you want to sell and after that the shop UI opens back up. This is awkward as hell and could be made much, much simpler.
Another example: You cannot access your recipes from within the cooking window. Why? Would seem natural to have a button for it there.
Or: You can only move around entries in your hotbar in the inventory, not during the main game. Seems unnecessarily clunky, too.

Another downside is that you can only equip 5 items at the same time. A weapon, an offhand item, an armor and two "misc" things (which is everything else, including helmets). And when you play a Budoka, you will only have three items...
That just isn't very much and the game should have taken hints from other RPGs that allow you a lot more. The biggest problem is that it just doesn't make sense that I cannot equip another ring if I already wear shoes and a helmet. It also limits the customization, which is a huge part in RPGs. One or two item slots more wouldn't have made a character overpowered.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]

In the end, you get a very fun and challenging roguelike  with a couple of downsides that I hope the developers will eventually improve for a thoroughly enjoyable experience.

This is easily one of my favorite roguelikes around. Easy to get into, great controls if you're using a game pad, and it's a deep game without just throwing 500 command choices at you.

The graphics are A+ and bring back the joyful memories of the SNES era, and hey, whoever designed the class system deserves a medal. It's a hell of a lot of fun to try and mix/match class abilites just to get that perfect warrior ready to climb the path to the surface. Also: Thanks to the devs for giving an option for those of us who sometimes don't want permadeath, I really appreciate the option to learn the game first before going into the real challenges.

Update: The cooking system is spiffy and easy to get used to, allowing you to just quickly make items from recipies, or add spices to it. Oddly though, it just coutns Garlic and Cilantro as spices to add into any dish. So Hey, If you've ever wanted Garlic Gelato, or Cilantro Mint Fudge, this is the game for you.

38636409.review:
Tangledeep is an absolute must-have for anyone looking for a more accessible (and much cuter) take on the traditional turn-based roguelike OR anyone craving that old-school JRPG charm, but with more complex gameplay to accompany it. It has truly captured the best of both worlds.

Accessible as the game is, that doesn't mean it's easy. The floors of Tangledeep are crawling with endless powerful enemies, healing abilities are limited and you will constantly have to exhaust your resources just to scrape by. Fortunately, the game offers a variety of tools to help you even the odds; the most obvious one being the highly flexible job system that allows you to switch jobs whenever you want and mix and match their skills to your heart's content. There's also weapon mastery skills you can learn to help tailor your playstyle around your favorite weapon types, ingredients and recipes you find to cook food for invaluable extra healing and buffs, item dream dungeons you can clear to upgrade your equipment, randomized "rumor" sidequests that reward you for completing optional objectives, planting seeds that grow over time into trees that you can harvest ingredients from, and even capturing monsters and raising them to fight alongside you! 

All of these add up to an experience that feels highly rewarding to players who take the time to explore their options and prepare for the dangers ahead, and it manages to make every death feel like a result of your own carelessness and not just another sacrifice to the Random Number God. And even though death is permanent, future characters can make use of any money or items you've stashed in the bank, trees you've grown and the monsters you've captured. This system of "investing" some of your stuff in future playthroughs is something I've really come to enjoy, because it allows you to make some permanent progress and make future runs go smoother without making it feel like your new characters are just downright better than the old ones. Very refreshing if you play a lot of "roguelites".

Tangledeep is also a beautifully presented game. The sprites, animation, sound effects and music channel the SNES era prefectly and are great in their own right, enemy and area designs are distinctive and easy to learn, the dialogue and flavor text is lighthearted and charming, and overall you can see the love that went into it. There are still some bugged visual effects and flaws in the UI to work out, but nothing has seriously hampered my experience so far. The developers work hard and are constantly releasing new builds and communicating with players. I'm happy to support them and I look forward to watching this great game get even better.

38494970.review:
It’s hard to describe the unique aesthetic the Super Nintendo had, a sort of warm, soft pixel look that made every game inviting and familiar. You’d be best off seeing it for yourself, either with the originals or faithful imitators like Super House of Dead Ninjas or TowerClimb. Now you can add Tangledeep to that list, not because it’s faithful to the look but because it captures so much of that classic 16-bit mystique. Few games are as lush and charming as this, even as it gleefully kills the fuck out of you.

You and your bestial kin live deep underground in an idyllic bastion of nature, but the allure of the mysterious surface proves too much for you to ignore. Between home and your goal lies the Tangledeep, a labyrinthine mess of fields, tunnels, thickets, forts, and other locales teeming with danger. You’re only going to survive the trip if you scavenge up some gear, make the most of your many skills, grow some plants, enter some item dreams, and cook a lot of meatwiches. There’s weirdness afoot in the subterranean wilds, and your journey is going to take you straight into the heart of it, should you survive.

Tangledeep shares a lot of DNA with kooky roguelikes like Dungeonmans and Dungeons of Dredmor, but with much of the silliness swapped out for additional polish and depth. At its heart is a turn-based dungeon crawl, with health and magic and stamina to manage as you cast skills and bump-murder enemies for loot. It’s worth mentioning that it plays better than a lot of its contemporaries, especially with a controller, thanks to some clean and intelligent UI design and silky-smooth game flow. Essential information like enemy health and area effects is always visible, and your own items and abilities are extremely clear in their functions.

That’s enough for a baseline roguelike, but Tangledeep makes good on its name with a dizzying knot of interconnected systems you can explore to find success. The ancient job system of Final Fantasy V and Tactics is resurrected here for the 12 playable classes, allowing you to earn and spend points for the skills you want before swapping to an entirely new class built atop those same skills. There’s also a weapon mastery system to spend those points on if you favor more direct combat. My floramancer was able to compliment her vine summoning and staff magic with area-of-effect elemental spells, making her a match for even large groups of monsters.

Beyond the vast potential of the job system, you’ll find a familiar RPG leveling scheme, randomized gear for five different equipment slots, a cooking system, a pet capture and care system, a simple farming system, and even the item dungeons from Disgaea if you want to fight the dreams of your hat to make it a better hat. And these are just what you can find in the base town, ignoring the side areas with casinos, pet shops, and even more off-beat options for building your legend. There’s so much you can do with your character that it’s easy to lose track of everything at your disposal, yet it’s never so pressing or overbearing that it detracts from the excellent, methodical combat.

You’ll need to focus heavily on that combat too, because like most quality roguelikes Tangledeep pulls no punches. You won’t often find yourself out of your depth thanks to clear difficulty indicators on the maps and enemies themselves, but you might be surprised at first how dangerous a Tricky or even Average threat can be. Certain design choices like no regenerating health or magic can make combat dicey until you learn to work around this particular style of challenge. It didn’t take me long to adjust but because it’s such a deep and involved game, losing a character stings more than it does in bite-sized romps like Isaac or Gungeon. Patience definitely helps keep you focused on your distant goal, and fortunately the look and feel are the right kind of soothing to keep you in that space.

I really can’t say enough good things about the aesthetic here. It’s not a perfect recreation of SNES graphics but it doesn’t need to be, and it hits all the right notes in all the right places to evoke that sense of wonder and comfort. The sound design is easily its equal too, with bright effects and tracks that hearken back to Secret of Mana and other giants of the genre. Few games are as vibrant as this one, and that joy it exudes makes the deep combat and vast progression systems so much more fun to explore and master. It’s right at the end of its Early Access cycle too, and feels far more complete than some full releases do. Tangledeep is a powerful addition to the roguelike genre, taking the best parts of nostalgia and fundamentals to produce something as enthralling as it is challenging.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11322459/]curation page[/url]!

Ah, THIS is what the 16 bit classics of the SNES era felt like at their time of release.  The music, the grapics; everything comes together beautifully.  The vision of the designers is something special.  I sit in the town and listen to that beautiful but melancholic melody play, and can't help but smile and feel at peace.  

Don't let the rogue-like nature scare you away.  There are three settings to play your way.  The challenge so far has avoided the "Cheap death" syndrome of many rogue-likes as well.  Plan well, don't tarry too long on any floor, and know when to retreat, you'll be fine.  

The class system is well done too.  You can buy a new class any time in town, and learn its abilities.  You can carry these over to a classes "class only" abilities, and create a nice hybrid powerhouse.  

Finally, there seems to be small story snippets every so many floor levels.  These are just the right length, and add color and that small push to keep you going to find out what is coming next.  

I'm enjoying myself very much now, and seriously looking forward to how it will be on full release!

If you loved the old 16 bit gems, roguelikes, or just want to support an Early Access game that isn't a scam and a developer that seems to really care... I can't recommend this game enough.

At the bottom of town there is a tree grove for planting seeds that grow diffrent trees yielding items as you progress.  There is also a monster pen, that I had very little expierence with since I accedentally killed the tutorial monster :P

All said and done, I enjoyed the experience, and have every intention to keep playing in the games current state, and I look forward to updates as they come and add new content.

35602021.review:
TANGLEDEEP (EARLY ACCESS – Sept 29 2017 Patch)

PUBLISHER – Impact Gameworks
DEVELOPER – Impact Gameworks
GENRE – Roguelike RPG action/adventure; 2.5D, indie

THE BASICS:
Tangledeep is a roguelike RPG action/adventure sort of dungeon crawler. It's presented in a 2.5D overhead style, in a fantasy setting. Pick from three difficulty settings : in Adventure Mode, the default setting, the game just shunts you back to town if you die, albeit with a noticeable EXP penalty and the loss of all of your gold and Job Points. In Heroic Mode, the intended setting, uses permadeath, but your town progress and banked items remain intact. In Hardcore Mode, you get the classic Rogue-type treatment: Everything goes away, including the town, your bank, and the save file itself, if you die.

THE FLOW AND THE STORY:
An idyllic little forest town is being threatened by all sorts of monsters – sentient and otherwise, all just as brutal – and guess whose job it is to deal with their abuse? That's right! Thus, it's time to make a character, decide their starting class and passive buffs, then go and gear up, grab some food and healing potions, and wade into the dungeon as its floors just keep going up and up and up...Higher floors mean tougher monsters, as well as better loot! How high can you climb and still stay alive? Just how far will you push your luck, and will it run out before you can make it back home with your little town portal or not? If you're feeling lucky, many floors will contain a “Pandora's Box” that, once activated, increases the local monsters' levels and gives them a buff, allowing you to find more of a challenge.

Each time you get to a new “floor,” one day will pass back in town. Your tree garden (if you've planted any seeds) will be harvested for its fruit, gems/shards, and/or spices; the critters you've captured and placed into your monster farm will have a chance to reproduce with one another (making better ones) and grow stronger; new quests and items will also become available at the vendors in town.

CONTROLS:
Keyboard (WASD or numpad) w/mouse, controllers, or mouse-only mode are supported. 8-way move in turn-based style, “move” towards an enemy for a basic attack, numbers from the top strip for shortcuts to special powers and attacks.

GRAPHICS:
Good-looking, highly detailed sprite-based everything. A bit cutesy at times, but in a way that suits the game and the environment. If anything, this may lead one to suspect that the game goes easy on you...It does not, and that's a good thing. Just when you're expecting to clear out an area and move on to some new little bonus region to explore, a pack of ninjas and lightning-throwing slimes all show up at once and proceed to teach you some humility. Or, you move onto a new floor, only to find the entrance to a bandit hideout, with signs warning you to stay away and let them conquer your little world in peace. Naturally, your first instinct is to ignore that warning and go kick their asses...doing so unprepared, however, will yield a swift GAME OVER. Gear up, load up on buffs, and come back, and maybe...just maybe...

SOUND:
Amazing music all around – from something gentle at the title screen to something a bit more tense when it's all about to hit the fan. SFX for hitting enemies, explosions, lightning crashes, at all, are all properly “meaty” as well.

OVERALL:
Feels like a solid followup to games such as Dungeonmans. Great music and atmosphere, straightforward gameplay. Accessible and fun!

SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS:
Minimal. XP SP2, Mac OSX 10.8+, Ubuntu 12.04 or Steam OS+ // 2GB Ram, CPU w/SSE support, DX9 or DX11 w/9.3 capabilities

REVIEW BY: Eric_Kei
Previously published on dlh.net

STORY: 85
GAMEPLAY: 85
GRAPHICS: 90
SOUND: 95
FUN FACTOR: 90
ATMOSPHERE: 90

Pros: 
Gorgeous sprite graphics, heavy on the details and animation

Wonderful music that really helps set the stage (from Zircon of OCZ fame, Hiroki Kikuta  (Secret of Mana), and Grant Kirkhope (GoldenEye 007 & Civilization: Beyond Earth))

The game gives you enough instruction to set you on your way with a feeling that you are ready to do what you need to do

Your monster farm, research archives, tree grove, and shared safe are all persistent between different characters, unless you play on Hardcore Mode.

Constantly getting patched; devs actively listen to players

You have the ability to change classes from time to time as you go.

Cons:
Some challenges that get thrown at you feel a bit harder than they really should be (e.g. “Kill monster X two floors up  from your last checkpoint before losing 200 HP”)

Tooltips on non-usable items tend to be rather vague (e.g. gem “leaves”)

Aw yeah, I love this roguelike -- everything about it is focused on making as fun of an experience as possible.

It's turn-based combat, but plays really smooth and fluid. It has tons of options between job classes to customize and play with how your character works, but not so much to where it seems overcomplicated or too hard to figure out. There's a lot of replayability since there're different ways to play through the game (distance fighter? hand-to-hand? magic-heavy? summoner? master chef?) and more to discover (...it'll take me a bit to get the hang of the soul-catcher class).

35348462.review:
Tangledeep is a deep and rewarding roguelike, with visual and audio themes reminiscent of the Mana series of RPGs and a mix-and-match class/ability system similar to Final Fantasy 5 or Final Fantasy Tactics. Other systems, such as the ability to raise monsters or to power up items by going into them and completing extra dungeon levels, are also incorporated into the game.

Essentially, it's a mixture of concepts from Legend of Mana, Final Fantasy, Disgaea, and Shiren the Wanderer (or Dungeons of Dredmor)!

However, it never feels particularly derivative - instead, this mixture of features from many JRPG franchises comes off as a logical progression of the genre, a fusion of ideas that have worked well separately into a set of systems that work even better together.

I couldn't recommend this game more, and it's only going to get better in the future - it feels more or less like a complete game now, but the developers have a lot more planned for inclusion.
