34068210.review:
There is so much to say about this game. Aside from the obvious (gorgeous old school pixel art and music that sounds direclty out of any given 90's JRPG,) Tangledeep feels like a long lost game from my childhood.

First and foremost, this is very much a real roguelike - but only if you want it to be. You can play it as a regular RPG if you desire, but it's clearly meant to appeal to roguelike fans. If you want meta-progression, it's there, but it's in no way necessary. If you don't want permadeath, you can play without it.

The crux of the game is a standard tower ascension dungeon crawl. You pick a starting job (class), and you're on your merry way. There are quests to help you progress, and the flexible job system lets you design any kind of character you can think of within the span of skills available to you. You may switch jobs at any given point, provided you have the necessary gold (or a special item.) All the skills you spent JP (the resource you use to buy skills) on will be kept when you switch jobs. You could, if you really wanted, learn one skill per job and just keep switching. Highly inefficient, but still possible.

The weapons classes in the game (i.e. sword, axe, bow, staff, etc...) all have a unique feature to them. For example, swords have an increased parry chance, and the ability to riposte upon parry, while axes hit all adjacent enemies. You can have four weapons equipped at once, which lends flexibility to each job. Some jobs clearly prefer certain weapon classes, of course; the Hunter works best with bows, while the Brigand works best with daggers, but these aren't hard rules (though some skills do require specific weapon types.)

There is no hunger clock. You *can* grind - though the usefulness of grinding diminishes heavily very quickly. Of note, your ability to heal is finite. You carry a flask which heals based on a percentage of your max health, and has a limited number of charges. You can refill these at fountains scattered throughout the dungeon, but these fountains are also finite. You can also heal through food and an NPC in town, but you will eventually run short on food if you mess around too much, and the NPC in town charges higher and higher prices to heal with each subsequent heal. So if you grind too long, you will probably lose the war of attrition.

The dev is amazing. This game is updated very frequently, each update bringing quality of life changes and bug fixes, and often times some content. I'm serious when I say it's updated *VERY* frequently. Like 4-5 times a week. The dev is friendly and communicative and fixes bugs pretty much right after they're caught. He is open to suggestions and seems to enjoy communicating with the players.

I keep forgetting this game is Early Access. It has a TON of content already, and quite a bit more on the way. There are currently 9 jobs, but 3 more are slated to be released before 1.0. There are so many ways to approach a win here, and that number will only increase. This is well worth the $15.

True modern roguelikes are uncommon, but this game fits the bill. Perhaps the most extreme purists won't see this as a true roguelike, but if you are playing on hardcore, I fail to see how it is anything but. I highly, HIGHLY recommend this game.

This game is wonderful, and reminds me a good bit of Tales of Maj'Eyal in many ways. 
Here's a quick rundown.
Pros:
- Lots of varied classes to choose from - no two of them feel alike.
- A great pixel art style that feels like it would be right at home on the SNES.
- Despite being in early access, it feels like a finished game - BUT I am still looking forward to even more content (especially new classes)!

33911993.review:
I've 18 hours spread out over a couple weeks, and I'm very impressed thus far. The score has drilled its way deep into my brain, and I'm pretty sure it's rewriting some neural pathways, because I'm tempted to scour everything else Zircon has composed to find some more gold nuggets.

So, the review. To set up: I'm an avid player of ARPG and have been since the SoM days. D2 through to D3 and Path of Exile hold most of my hours, while sampling various MMORPGs along the way. But in the last 5-6 years, I've been getting more into rogue-like games. I'm not ashamed to say I've sunk 173 hours into FTL. Lastly, to disclose: I'm backer of Tangledeep.

Tangledeep definitely scratches that FTL itch, and carries an equally strong soundtrack. The game mechanics are unique in its turn-based move/action style. This aspect, combined with NECESSARY resource management (flasks/food), make for gameplay that is challenging, yet brisk.

As far as an Alpha goes, it's much more polished than expected, and is HIGHLY playable at this stage. I blew through 6 characters before I got the hang of how you need to balance and manage healing, and mitigate or minimize damage. Health/HP is a commodity, and does not automatically replenish.

While the game art feels dated, even in a simulated-retro-8bit sort of way, it still carries 100% of the charm that the author was no doubt shooting for - and is a remarkable achievement considering the size of the team.  Replayability is extremely high; if this was a goal of the developer, it really shows.

Lastly, I can't emphasize enough how promising the soundtrack is at this stage. There are several excellent songs that will really grow on you if you're a fan of VGM.  If I read correctly, I think the developer is going to release two versions of each song - the in-game one that simulates more of the midi feel, and another more polished, hi-fidelity version. If this is the case, it might be worth checking out the Kickstarter, or scooping up the deluxe version if they offer it in Steam.

33849853.review:
I like ADOM. ADOM is a fun romp through a large world with dozens of classes, hundreds of items, and all sorts of other cool things.

Tangledeep, however, is not ADOM. Obviously it's in Early Access, and I've only put an hour into it so far, so I can say that as of now it's a little less complex than ADOM... but it is also a MASSIVE step-up in UI and interface quality over all the other roguelike games I've played.

There are 9 jobs you can pick at the start of the game. Each job has a whole bunch of abilities you can purchase permanently as you play through, and you will keep these abilities if you switch to another class. However, the classes also have passive abilities that are locked to only that class, and if you switch you lose them. This means you can play through and learn every active ability in the game, but you also have to make choices about how to build your character since you can't have everything all at once.

Item variety is pretty good, but I imagine this will be expanded to the level of ADOM in the future.

The art in this game is very nice, the colors pop, the catgirls look nice, etc. I think the only characters in this game are female, I didn't see a single male (Or I wasn't looking hard enough) so that means lots of spriting eye-candy.

The UI is really phenomenal though, seriously. I've been bashing my head against rocks every time I play a roguelike and they put zero or minimal effort into user accessibility. Even in ADOM, just comparing two pieces of equipment to each other is a chore. Here, it's a cinch.

Lots of game altering options to choose from too, etc.

As of right now, it's a good 6/10 overall, and a 9/10 for presentation. You might think 6/10 is bad, but this is an above average Early Access game, since I'm using the Moist Meter system of rating, and not the IGN numerical system where anything below a 7 is terrible.

This game is missing many things, due to being in Early Access, like 'advanced jobs' and other things that simply don't work and haven't been added yet, but the amount of polish already present in the game tells me the developer is taking the product seriously.

I would say that buying it at full price is fine, and any form of a sale is definitely worth it.

33818905.review:
Full disclosure: I backed this game's Kickstarter.

While at the time of this writing the game is still receiving new features and bugfixes, Tangledeep is already a marvelous gem. Designed, coded, and even scored by one man (which brings to mind the likes of Pixel and his work on Cave Story), Tangledeep feels like the kind of rougelike we might have gotten on an enhanced SNES, if one were ever made for today's audiences.

The soundtrack is literally what sold me on this game; I didn't even have a computer ready to play the alpha builds (since there was no Linux support yet), so I backed the Kickstarter based *solely* on screenshots and the existing soundtrack, which is still available to listen to on zircon's SoundCloud and is probably now all over YouTube. Only the chiptune versions are in the game last I checked, but MAN are they good. It really is a mixture of some of the best parts of SNES soundtracks' glory days, injected with its own soul; it may *sound* familiar, but it *feels* like a truly new soundtrack.

Linux support was added well before early access, and I at last played the game the week prior. Controller support is already pretty good, at least with a wired Xbox 360 pad (keyboard plus mouse and just mouse or just keyboard are also perfectly doable; I just really like using gamepads), and the game is not a performance hog at all, so I imagine that any laptop will be able to run this with ease as long as it meets the OpenGL requirement in hardware (version 4.1, I think). Mine doesn't, though, so I played on my desktop.

The gameplay itself lends itself well to exploration of both the dungeons and the mechanics! I've only tried out two jobs and have yet to make it past 11F; but there's plenty of loot to enhance yourself with; loads of enemies that will keep you on your toes, including minibosses; and combat options galore to help you get out of that sticky situation *if* you plan things out well. I can get impatient at times so I'll just hack-hack-hack at most enemies, but the tricky situations that demanded me to make the most of my items and spells in order to get out alive are satisfying to take a moment and ponder over; and when I die, it's usually my fault, even if I don't always realize this until it's too late.

I suppose I never was great at roguelikes.

Anyway, I suppose I'm rambling at this point. If you like rougelikes and you like SNES-like chiptunes - or any of zircon's work on, say, OverClocked ReMix, then this game is worth checking out, even in Early Access. I think you'll love it.

33689557.review:
SUMMARY: An addictive, fun, and deep "continuing Roguelike" of dungeon exploration and character building, with a story to boot.  Explore a dungeon, unlock mysteries, raise trees and monsters, save the day - or leave a legacy for the next adventurer when you die.  With highly engaged devs, this game is a must-buy for RPG/Roguelike fans.

Tangledeep is, well, deep.  It's got the candy-color 16 bit look, but as you dive into it, you keep finding there's more to the game.  Like any good dungeon, there's more the farther you go.

Only, you're kind of climbing up, because you live at the bottom of what's technically the dungeon.

You start out in an underground town, creating a character and deciding to explore the "Tangledeep" that leads to the surface.  On a basic level we've seen it before - get a character, wander through randomized dungeons, find stuff, gain skills, kill things.  You can die, but you can bank items, corral monsters, and plant trees to assist your replacement.  So you can be a wizard or warrior, but also a farmer and a practitioner of animal husbandry.  Oh, but there's more

See, as you go on more and more potential comes out.
* Each character is very distinct, and their skills invite differnt strategies.  However you can . . .
* Swap classes as you have the resources and carry over the same skills (but not unique class bonuses).  Ever want to be a giant armored tank that shoots magic?  Tangledeep has you covered.
* Learn other skills in town to further specialize your character.
* Random quests are assigned in town to give you a chance to advance.  How many do you want to queue up?
* Corral monsters for all sorts of benefits.  Groom them.  Feed them.  Get gifts.  Take them on adventures with you!  Breed them to make stronger companions!  Monsters stay around even when your adventurer dies - a good monster buddy can make re-exploring much faster.
* Plant trees to get food and other benefits - or chop them down for experience.  Trees will be around even when your adventurer dies.
* Learn to cook various dishes with bonuses and healing.
* Bank items and gold for future adventurers.  Speaking of items . . .
* Items bring various bonuses.  Ever want to have armor that summons attack crabs?  Magical books that create shields in front of you?  You'll have to choose your loadout carefully (fortunately the game allows you to configure four weapon slots).
* Unlock the ability to enter the Dreams of items, unlocking randomized or specific powers.  Or maybe you want to take a power away - you can do that to.  Explore imaginary dungeons with real danger - and real rewards, including leveling up items.

On top of all of this there's a plot and backstory.  Tangledeep has it all.

Tangledeep is a game with a lot of depth, a lot of heart, and a lot going for it.  It's clear the team enjoy games and asked "what would be fun?"  Then they keep shoveling fun out.

Who's it for?
* If you love "continuing Roguelikes" like Dungeonmans or Shiren, go for it.  End of story.  You should have this.
* If you like a good challenging RPG.  This has it all.
* If you want a bit of retro with modern polish.
* If you want to climb deep into an RPG's character and item crafting.
* If ANYONE you know fits the above, you just found a great fit.

33645676.review:
I'm a Kickstarter backer of this game. 

Tangledeep is an excellent turn-based roguelike with a beautiful graphical style inspired by the 16-bit SNES era. It has a deep job system inspired by Final Fantasy 5, a few persistent elements, really nice music, and a well done mouse interface. The developer is a hard working and a responsive cool guy. 

Just coming in to early access Tangledeep already feels very far along and you can get lots of enjoyment out of it in it's current state. You can play it in hardcore mode, which is the roguelike way of things with permadeath, or in a non-hardcore mode where you return to your basecamp on death. 

In terms of complexity it falls somewhere between traditional roguelikes like Nethack, DCSS, and ADOM and lighter, more mobile oriented ones, like Golden Krone Hotel, Sproggiwood and Desktop Dungeons.  

On the negative side it's feels a bit too easy at the moment. I hope the difficulty either gets boosted a bit or they add a "harder core" mode with more challenge (maybe something with sliders...). It'd also be nice to see some more challenging boss-fights. JRPGs are famous for their boss-fights and that side doesn't really come across in Tangledeep.
